Fields.DialogueText: Sayako?
Oh - Kanchou! Gomen! I didn't see you there.

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry about it.
Sorry if I startled you.
Yeah, I've been practicing my sneaking skills.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay. But I am sorry.
No, no! I'm sorry!
... I can respect that, actually. But as for myself, I should have-
Stop. Staring off into space when you're not on duty isn't exactly a crime.
Did you make it into the city?
Hm?
Brest. We've been trying to let the crew get a little time on shore to try to get in touch with loved ones or get a different kind of meal or....
Did you really not know?
... I've just been working and sleeping. I haven't really felt like doing anything else since....
You know.
Yeah. I know I said it before, but I really am sorry you didn't get to talk to him. August was looking for you, but-
No, he found Fanny first, and I'm glad. It made him happy.
Mr. Granville, I mean. I don't suppose it made August's day a whole lot brighter.
... I wouldn't have known what to say, anyway.

Fields.MenuText: Right. So, how're you doing?
You know, we have a chaplain. Just in case you ever need to talk to someone who's been ordered by God to be nice to you.
I take it you knew Bertie for a while.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm fine. Thank you very much for asking.
Good! Now, for real, how are you?
Heh.
... Sort of. He was someone my father knew when I was a kid, in San Diego. After we left Japan.
But I only really got to know him a couple of years ago. He hired me to be Fanny's traveling companion.
... I mean, really, he was paying me to let her try to keep me out of trouble.
Did it work?
I mean, I thought so, but she left me behind the first chance she got, so...
I'm sorry. That was... that was unfair.
... Are you okay?
As long as I have work to do, I don't have to think, so I'm fine.
I get that.
You're going to have to throw us all off the ship eventually, though, right?
We all know it. Even if your bosses let you stay in command, there's no way they'll let August and Enoch and Orest stay on as officers once you can get official replacements.
Never mind the crazy Japanese girl with the American accent and the criminal record.

Fields.MenuText: "The criminal record?"
It's all up in the air.
You're my crew. If I stay on, I'm not letting go of you without a fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Trespassing. They could never prove breaking and entering.
... Is there a story?
I just really wanted to see how ships are made.
Hai, hai.
That's nice of you to say, Kanchou.
Fair enough.
You know Fanny's trying to convince the world that this ship is a showcase, right? International crew, women on active duty - all a model for the future.
Fanny's trying to tell a bunch of old men things that they won't want to hear. I wouldn't count on her changing the world.
I've had a few talks with people around the docks. Have you heard of Captain Ferneck? "The Ace of the Kriegsmarine?"
You know a flying ace, back in the last war, was a pilot who'd shot down at least five enemy aircraft? Apparently Captain Ferneck's ship sank five Morganas in the Baltic.
His entire crew got the Iron Cross. He's apparently got the discretion to do almost anything he likes. Before we came along, he was the great symbol of resistance against the new enemy.
... How many Morganas have we sunk?
I lost track somewhere in the thirties.
People may not know what to make of us, but I don't think they're going to be in a hurry to break us up either.
*ALARM*
... Apologies if I just jinxed us.
@BATTLE
Hm.
Get to action stations! This isn't a drill!
@BATTLE
Hello, Doctor. That time again?
I don't know why you're complaining. I'm the one who has to hoof it all the way to the bridge just to take your pulse and listen to you cough.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry. I just have other things on my mind after a battle.
I think by now we can assume it won't be the mist that does me in.
In fairness, the exercise has got to be doing you some good.

Fields.DialogueText: I resent your honesty and your cold appreciation of the facts.
Maybe so. But, still, here I am. I just think it wouldn't be fair to deny you all my scintillating conversation.
Don't worry. This doesn't take long.
Cough for me.

Fields.MenuText: *cough*
Only because you asked so nicely.

Fields.DialogueText: *cough*
Good. You've got the lungs of an acting captain half your age.
Actually, it's apparently not "acting" anymore. I haven't seen the paperwork yet, but the word is my battlefield promotion is being made official.
So you're missing out on that nice, long vacation in the brig? They must really have it in for you.
I admire how you're avoiding the overly predictable route of congratulations and parties.
Right. Well, I admit, congratulations are in order. I'm not sure the ship's in a partying mood, though.
Yeah. It's been a hard month.
It was an impossible month. And it's just setting in that that's the new normal.
You heard the fighting's stopped in the Hel Peninsula? On land, I mean.
I haven't heard anything. For some reason, my commanding officer hasn't seen fit to let me go ashore to get a newspaper and try to call my kids.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry about that.
You know we've needed you here.
I'm not going to sugar-coat this. We can't afford to have you disappear on a bender. Not in wartime.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't I just.
Yeah.
I doubt that's in me.
Now shut up for a second so I can listen to your heart.
Right. I can confirm you've officially survived another battle.
Thanks.
... If I sign off on giving you a night off in Brest, you better not drink anything more interesting than coffee.
No, sir.
And you'll get your butt back here by 11:00 tomorrow.
Aye-aye.
Fine. If sick bay can spare you, go try to call your kids.
Thank you, Captain.
Captain? What's going on?
We don't have time for a briefing, Lieutenant. We need to be clear of port within the hour!
He's really a lieutenant now? That's official?
Lugin, just get to your post, okay?
My life is just a string of bizarre and nonsensical accidents.
You mean, "Yes, sir."
Da, da. I thought it was implied.
Captain, should we be sounding the klaxon? Are there incoming-
Probably, but that's not the problem - there's apparently a Morgana armada coming south out of the North Sea. I want us to be close enough to assist if we're needed.
"Armada?"

Fields.MenuText: It's not clear that they're organized, but the... migration seems to be significant. Maybe a hundred ships.
Briefing later! Get moving!
Starting to miss your cargo ship, Lieutenant?

Fields.DialogueText: Sh... Understood, Captain.
Right!
Actually, I find the massive guns here to be really reassuring.
Fair point.
*ALARM*
It figures.
@BATTLE
Every way we turn. Are we going to be able to tell the difference when the armada shows up?
I'll have to refrain from answering that question. Or thinking about it.
Captain? Radio interference is bad, but we seem to have confirmation that the enemy's been sighted all along the Dutch coast. They're saying Rotterdam is the likely target, but I don't know why.
I understand.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
What they're basing the evaluation on, I mean. If it's just ship movements or intercepted communications or....

Fields.MenuText: Did you say you had family in Rotterdam?
Keep listening. Let me know if you hear more.

Fields.DialogueText: Amsterdam.
Diamonds. Right.
Hopefully they're out of harm's way. Relatively speaking.
Ja. Of course.
If there's anything-
Wonderful.
Kanchou! The Pharmacist's Mate wanted me to tell you that there isn't going to be a report anytime soon because he doesn't know what he's doing.

Fields.MenuText: Great.
Were those his exact words?
Really, how's he doing?

Fields.DialogueText: The good news is that we're probably not going to lose anyone else.
There was more incoherent screaming in the original version.
Actually, for a man who'd never planned to be a field surgeon, I think he's doing okay. Though I think he's planning even harder not to be a field surgeon again.
Captain?
Ohayō, Grumpy-kun!
Hello there, demon girl.
Captain, the latest word is that the Morgana movement is... well, they think it's separating.
The armada?
Right. Again, assuming this isn't disinformation or-
Right.
Is that good?
No. Nothing they do is ever good. I don't know why it isn't good, but it isn't.
Never mind. We're continuing toward Rotterdam until we get a better picture of what's going on.
Will the Doctor be taking a train to join us, you think?
I can think of a guy in the infirmary who would pay for the tickets.
There is, Captain. Headed straight for us.
Right. Here's the situation as I understand it.
For the past several weeks, Britain has been trying to move infantry to the Continent in anticipation of a larger land war.
Now the British side is escalating, and the Morganas have diverted some of their northern forces to make life rough between Dover and Calais - and to impede traffic in a wider sense.
I don't think it's been going well.
Other Morganas are settling into the Skagerrak Strait. German forces are already getting antsy about access to Norwegian iron, and it's increasingly possible that the Baltic could be sealed off.
And, yes, Rotterdam is still under attack. By a smaller force, but still - I'm told this is Europe's largest port, and it's locked down.
You see? Good news for once. Nothing we do can make things worse.
I bet you a crate of beer you'll regret saying that.
You don't ever have to regret what you say if you're willing to lie about having said it.
Thank you, gentlemen. Shut it.
So what are we doing, Kanchou?
First things first. We're nearly at Rotterdam, so we clear it out. And hopefully secure a new surgeon until we can collect our wayward friend.
I may also be able to get you a bomber if you're willing to trade a few favors.
... Pardon me?
He's serious. I don't know how he does it, but procuring weird sh... things is kind of his specialty.
Nyet. It's my passion.
Right. Table that for now.
A bomber. Flies overhead, drops terrible murder parcels, blasts your enemies out of their shoes.
We're heading for Rotterdam - and, Mr. Cassel, I want us coming in loud. I want you on the radio calling for the Morganas' surrender.
At least some of them will be crazy enough to come after us instead of chewing up civilian targets.

Fields.MenuText: Once that's done, maybe we can see about clearing the Manche - or the English Channel, if you prefer.
Once that's done, maybe we can see about opening the bottleneck over Denmark.
Once that's done, maybe we can finally collect our doctor before he can get himself into trouble.

Fields.DialogueText: That. Is so. Amazing.
Please don't encourage him.
Any questions?
Any word from Poland?
I was going to ask if I could get a bomber, but that's definitely a better question.
It sounds like it's just about done. Hitler's flown into Warsaw to gloat.
The Morganas didn't even slow him down, huh?
Well, the son of a bitch didn't sail to Warsaw, so... no.

Fields.MenuText: Poland isn't lost just because Hitler says it is, August.
Talk politics on your own time, people. We're back on the clock now.
It's an interesting point. If the Morganas were trying to stop German progress, they failed.

Fields.DialogueText: Da. It's lost because it has enemies on all sides and its friends are issuing press releases.
Understood, Captain.
Thanks for that, Lugin.
I'd prefer to leave that unexplored.
Right. I'm heading back to the bridge. Good luck, everyone - expect shooting sooner rather than later.
@BATTLE
Or at least moving it further west.
And spoil his vacation?
Whichever needs us more. You'll find us neutral on that front.
So, I hear you're finally entitled to sew however many stripes on your sleeve. Congratulations, if you're into that sort of thing.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you.
Sewing, Lugin. I can never get enough.
At least it suggests they're not going to pull the ship out from under me.

Fields.DialogueText: Hrm. So, what are you looking for out here?
Really?
Da. Really.
The second Morgana group that's been terrorizing Rotterdam.
Oh, right. I heard something about that.
Will this be it, then? When these ones are gone? Have we all but saved the city?
We've mitigated the carnage, maybe. You'll have to ask the people there if they feel saved.
I'm really just asking if I'll be able to stop off and scare up some cigarettes.
I wouldn't count on it.
Hrm. War is hell.
I was serious about that bomber, by the way. If you let me throw your name around in a few places....

Fields.MenuText: Noted.
Forgive the cynicism, but: what's in it for you?

Fields.DialogueText: We can use it, da? I mostly like not being dead.

Fields.MenuText: Some other time.
Sure. We need all the terrible murder parcels we can get.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Most people don't remember my glorious turns of phrase!
Saves us having to make room for it, I suppose.
But most of the Morganas we were worried about just went in slightly different directions. I don't think two days of fighting are going to solve the problem.
Hey. Look over there. Is that-?
... Da. We are in luck. It is hundreds of tons of evil metal terror bastards.

Fields.MenuText: ... Would you be interested in writing for the ship's newspaper?
Couldn't have put it better myself.
Next time, just stop at "Da."

Fields.DialogueText: I try not to attach my name to anything officers might read.
So. Do we have a doctor yet? You know, so I can know how much effort I have to put into not getting blown up?
I think we have someone lined up in Rotterdam. She should keep us going until we can pick our first doctor up.
A woman?
So I'm told. Is that a problem?
It could be. What if she's fatally distracted by Cassel's manly charms?
Who isn't? It's a risk we'll have to take.
@BATTLE
Rank really does have its privileges.
Any time. Sir.
Of course not. The only way it's coming out from under you is if they shoot it.
The Morganas, not-
I gathered.
Da.
We're heading back west, then?
Not very far. We just need to keep the Morganas from consolidating their gains between southern England and northern France.
"Just?"

Fields.MenuText: Poor choice of words, granted.
You're expected to find my optimism inspirational, Lieutenant.
We've had harder missions.

Fields.DialogueText: Has it been bad, Kanchou? In the Channel?
Worse than they've made public, that's for sure. And the worry is that the Morganas can use their stolen resources to improve themselves faster than we can sink them.
Yeah, I don't think that's....
No, sorry. Never mind.
Lieutenant - and this goes for all of you - if you're censoring yourself in front of the captain, don't. I need all the input I can get.
Ha. Bertie would've loved hearing that.
Handkerchief?
I don't know that I was censoring myself, Captain. It's just that this could get political in a way that the mess out in the Atlantic didn't.
It's one thing to get everybody to agree that the Morganas are a common enemy in the abstract - it's another thing to convince Germany the Brits should be able to transport ground forces unmolested.
Hitler just called for an armistice, right? Maybe the land war is already over.
Listen, the Nazis need to show strength. Domination. That's the only thing holding them together. Until Versailles is avenged, they're not going to stop - and it'll never be avenged enough for them.
No.
No?
Plus, clearly, they're going to end up blaming the Morganas on the Jews somehow. Whatever pretext they can get for robbing us blind and kicking us out of our homes....
No offense, man - but that's part of what I'm getting at.
I'm not saying you're wrong about the Nazis, but... look, I spent a few years studying the fall of the Mughal Empire.
What? Did you lose a bet?
Ahem.
Shush. Look, I'm not an expert, but one thing I took away is that the Brits didn't just show up one day and take over.
The folks who lived in India first had their own politics and their own rivalries and their own complicated equilibrium to tweak or maintain. Right?
Like, the pre-existing order is a human body. A lot of stuff has to be in balance to stay healthy.
And an effective invader just has to be a successful disease. It's simpler. You get in, grab territory, replicate yourself. Make the system react to you, and it breaks down.
And Europe is compromised to begin with?
Europe. The whole world.
Cassel, man, you've been fighting for your life against the Morganas every day for a month, and I can tell just from listening to you here that you're angrier at the Nazis than you are at them.
And I can understand that! Honestly, if you assume the Morganas are just crazy monsters, then they're less morally culpable than a lot of other folks out there.
And that's one of the strongest weapons they have - there's just so much bad history on our side. I see your point.

Fields.MenuText: I'm starting to regret telling you to speak freely, Lieutenant.
All we can do is fight it with our eyes open.
So what?

Fields.DialogueText: One of the privileges of my job is that I don't have to worry about the big picture. I fight what's in front of me, and the thing after that, and the thing after that.
And it's the same for all of you, if you haven't realized it yet. You're entitled to accept that there's a lot out there that's out of your hands.
What you can affect, what you can make better, is what's in front of you. It's the mission. It's the moment. That's your responsibility.
And, so far, it's been my experience that doing it well matters. That, paradoxically, it does make a bigger difference.
I'd be lying if I said we knew the full measure of our new enemy here - the virus in your metaphor.
But the rest of us, the warring nations of the world - we're just people. Yeah, we have our biases and we have our prejudices, but we're wired to form groups.
I think the worst of our tensions and our conflicts and our wars come when the people in power have the privilege to think that they can choose their enemies.
We're wired to trust each other once we start working together.
I don't think that's the case here. I have to believe that even Hitler has to realize that August's family are less threatening than an enemy with limitless resources and no connection to human life.
And, if not, to hell with him.
Yeah, I got that a lot from my advisor.
Heh.
Oh, hey. Did I tell you guys I talked to Fanny?
I'm glad Lugin isn't here to say something snide about that.
No. How's she doing?
Oh, you know. She's... I mean, she's Fanny.
But she's aiming for the 31st. For the conference in Zurich.
Halloween? That's... ambitious.
Has anyone actually agreed to go?
*ALARM*
Right. Table that for now.
@BATTLE
And missions that were supposed to be easier.
Eh. You're not the one who shifted the paradigm.
I'll manage.
Captain on the bridge!
What's the situation, Lieutenant?
They're almost in range, sir.
So they are.
By the way, Lieutenant?
Captain?
I don't have to tell you to be careful about comparing the British in India to a virus around British crewmembers, do I?
No, sir. And if I have to do it, I'll make sure to insult the French at the same time.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad we had this talk.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Hey, if you're going to be fair, knock all the colonial powers.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll keep that in mind, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: No.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Okay. I'll be careful.
This feels... almost strange. Our regular doctor made a habit of checking my vitals on the bridge after a battle.
Are you having trouble walking?

Fields.MenuText: Diagnosed with acute sloth at a young age.
No.
It was more that the entire bridge crew collapsed at once back at the start of the war. He's a little bit edgy now.

Fields.DialogueText: Get over it.
Good.
He's also not here.
I may be new to life on a ship, but I can't imagine that giving the Captain special treatment would be good for morale.

Fields.MenuText: I honestly think the old doctor was looking for conversation as much as anything else.
Point taken.
Well, I'll warn you now - you're probably not going to see me if I'm not spitting out blood.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not.
I get that.
Good.
If you're not spitting out blood, I probably don't need to see you.
You're in reasonably good health. You could probably do with more exercise, but I don't think you're going to shuffle off this mortal coil without outside help.
Glad to hear it.
Now, I should say, your regular doctor left a hell of a lot of clutter in my workspace - including alcohol I'd be afraid to use to strip varnish.
I don't judge, but it's in my way. If you don't want me to throw it overboard, you should find-
Captain!
Captain, we have a mess to sort out.

Fields.MenuText: Tell me.
... Doctor, I may need that booze.

Fields.DialogueText: We've received a distress call from a German sub, the U-12.
They hit a British mine - apparently the only reason they're not at the bottom of the ocean is that the Morganas caught them and dragged them to the surface.
They're trying to crack them open. The Morganas.
Where? Close?
Near Dover, Captain. British waters.
Fantastic. I'll meet you on the bridge.
Doctor - welcome aboard.
Seconded!
@BATTLE
Solve one problem with another.
What's the latest from Doctor van Geffen?
Six survivors from U-12, out of a total crew of twenty-seven. She thinks four are out of the woods and she's doing what she can for the other two.
The British would like them turned over, by the way.
We don't have time. We don't have anything like time.
Captain?
Morganas are making another play for Rotterdam - and they're coming in harder this time. Captain Ferneck and the Admiral Scheer headed the defense and are presumed lost.
Ferneck. Was he the "naval ace?"
I hope he still is. Somehow.
Right now, we're looking to intercept a Morgana destroyer group basically right next to the Hague before they can reinforce the main attack.

Fields.MenuText: Any questions?
Get some rest over the next couple of hours if you can. It's going to get rough.
So basically just another Tuesday for us.

Fields.DialogueText: Well... one other point of order, Captain. If you have time.

Fields.MenuText: Go.
What is it, August?
I don't have time, but don't let that stop you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well... apparently Sayako has been working as a "wiper" with the engines. Is that right?
Mm-hm.
Only, the engineers say she's actually a really good "oiler," and they want to make that official. Sir.
... Are you saying they want to promote her after two weeks?
I'll admit, I'm still kind of oblivious about ranks. Just in general. But if we're all still alive in a year, they say they'll recommend her for formal engineering training.
Huh.
Right now, though, I'm going to go shut my eyes. I'll see you both when the shooting starts.
@BATTLE
If she can do the job, I have no objections. Have them send me whatever I need to sign.
God help us on Wednesday.
Wide awake, Captain. Wouldn't have it any other way.
None of us have had time for at least a month.
I don't like smelling smoke when all we can see is mist. One is bad enough all on its own, don't you think?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah.
At least it means we're headed in the right direction.
If you have the energy to complain, they must not be working you hard enough.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai! Exactly! Make them give me more work!
... Okay. Not the reaction I was expecting.
Hai. I suppose.
... August tells me the Morganas destroyed a famous bridge?
Don't worry. They know you're good. You'll hammer a schedule out.
Thank you, Kanchou.
So I'm told. The Willemsbrug. I don't know how they did it, but apparently the locusts are making off with tons of steel.
And the civilian death toll is in the hundreds. At least. The mist doesn't seem to be as bad as it was in the early days, but...
Bad enough.
Mm-hm.
I wish Bertie were here.

Fields.MenuText: I know.
Me, too.

Fields.DialogueText: I bet Fanny's talked the Italians around by now. She thought they would be the easiest to convince.
Compared to whom?
When we were all talking about the war, a few days ago, I noticed you sort of went out of your way not to say it would all come down to us.

Fields.MenuText: Did I?
That's because it won't. It's a group effort, all the way.
I didn't want to add to the stress.

Fields.DialogueText: I thought so.
But winning here, now... that seems like it could really matter, right?
It certainly would to the people of Rotterdam.
*ALARM*
Time to get going, Seaman Kirishima.
... That will never not make me want to giggle.
Let's try that again. Time to get going, Seaman.
Hai! On my way, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
With all due respect, that ship's sailed.
The radio room is yours, Mr. Cassel.
Thank you, Captain.
... Is everything all right?
I just had a minor chewing out. I'll survive it.
This is because of your... message to the Dutch?
I don't recall sending a message to the Dutch.
I mentioned the Zurich Conference to some reporters and I said that the Netherlands' participation could be important - but that was all just public knowledge. No editorializing at all.
Subtle. Do you think it did any good?

Fields.MenuText: I don't think it was even needed. The Dutch know what we're all facing now.
I hope so.
No, seriously. I wasn't being subtle. I was just sleep-deprived and rambling to journalists.

Fields.DialogueText: So it's just the rest of the world we have to worry about.
Right.
Let the history books figure that one out.
Anyway, for now I want us back in the Channel. Officially, we're on a fact-finding mission.
Unofficially... for one thing, I want to be close to the Skagerrak Strait. I don't like the idea of a Morgana blockade, and I don't like the rumors I'm hearing that they're building in the Baltic.
Building like in the "this is how it ends" film?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know.
Let's hope not.
Probably wisest to assume the worst.

Fields.DialogueText: And... look, I'm sorry for asking, but what about the actual war?
I mean, if German submarines are prowling in British waters and the Brits are blowing them up... what happens when that escalates?
*ALARM*
Don't read too much into that.
@BATTLE
Whenever we find out what that might be.
I've been over it night after night... whether I want to or not... and can't make sense of it.
Good job on replenishing the food stores, Lugin. Conventional supply lines have been... tricky.
See if you thank me in a week.
... Why?
The bananas.
We'll make sure they're eaten before the smell gets too... hey!
Well, well. Look who the cat coughed up.
Permission to stagger aboard, Captain?
You're a little bit late, Doctor.
You left before ten in the morning. You said I had until ten.
Tsk.

Fields.MenuText: That'll be all, Mr. Lugin.
Lugin, we're done here - but go ahead and call in those favors. If you can get me a diver, I want him.

Fields.DialogueText: Da. Welcome back, Doctor. Sorry about all your vodka!
What.
It's just a matter of getting him out of jail, Captain. Don't worry - your name will open all the right doors!
Fantastic.
So I see you managed to survive without me. Our child pharmacist stepped up?
We brought in a second doctor at Rotterdam. Between the battles. She's been immensely helpful.
We had to clear out some of your less traditional supplies to make room for-
You got rid of my tonics!?

Fields.MenuText: I'm pretty sure the word is technically "contraband."
You know as well as anyone that space is at a premium, Doctor.
To be fair, it's nothing Lugin can't replace.

Fields.DialogueText: Medical. Necessities.
I was only gone for ten days!
Lugin wouldn't know quality liquor if the word "quality" was written on the label in giant golden letters!
I have it on good authority that the stuff you drink compares unfavorably to turpentine.
Then somebody has no doubt received a serious head wound since I left and is raving deliriously without my care!
*ALARM*
... Is sick bay still where I left it?
More or less.
Try to make sure we don't need to use it, okay?
@BATTLE
The day after the ship left, I honestly wasn't planning on coming back.
Not the sort of thing you generally say in front of the Captain.

Fields.MenuText: No, no. By all means, let him keep digging.
Since he did come back, he gets a pass.
I don't think there's anybody at this table who hasn't fantasized about not getting shot at.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't mind if I do.
See? Command instincts. Always said you had 'em.
It's not the getting shot at.
... I never did get to talk to my kids.
I spent a lot of time thinking about what I was going to say. How you tell a ten-year-old that what you're doing is important enough to be worth...
To be worth all of this nonsense.
And, I'll tell you, when you're lying on a hotel bed at three in the morning, there comes a moment when it hits you that it's not worth it.
That there's not a thing you do that somebody younger and smarter couldn't do better. And that's a hard thought when your job is keeping kids from bleeding out in a dark hallway in a talking bathtub.
When you all left early, I honestly did think it was a sign. I was just going to go home and see what happened.

Fields.MenuText: You would've been arrested for desertion and brought back in chains.
No, you weren't.
So what happened?

Fields.DialogueText: ... That wasn't immediately clear at the time.
I damn well thought I was.
Y'know, I don't know.
I mean, if I'd known you were going to replace me with a tee-totaling harridan the instant I was out of your sight-
You weren't replaced. You've been supplemented.
But anyway, you're glad to be back, right? Because we did miss you.
... I don't remember you being this covered in grease before I left. Did you stop washing your hands in grief?
No. I got my dream job.
... Are you joking? Captain, is she joking?
The girl likes her motor oil.
You didn't answer her question, though. Should we worry about you making a break for it the next time we're in port?
Hey, you outrank me. You get to decide what you worry about.
But I can say I realized that I don't want to know what it feels like to realize one of you idiots was gone and I didn't even try to keep it from happening.
I think-
If you're going to give one of those big, morale-building speeches you do, can we just count it as done? I really need to hit the head.

Fields.MenuText: But it was going to be a good one.
No. This is your punishment for doubting yourself.
I don't give big, morale-building speeches. Do I?

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes. But they're really good!
Dammit.
You can give it to Enoch and me!
*ALARM*
Oh, that just figures.
You should have time to take care of business, Doctor. Just hurry.
And thank you for waiting for us.
@BATTLE
Captain?
Morganas are almost in firing range, Mr. Cassel. I think we owe it to the people of Guernsey not to be distracted when the shooting starts.
I know, sir. But we've been getting a radio broadcast. I think it's from them, but it's-
Just tell me quickly.
They say that yesterday the Brits sank a U-boat. U-45. And they say a U-boat hit Scapa Flow and sank HMS Royal Oak.
I don't know how much of it is true and how much is just them trying to get in our heads, but... we're not going to be the only ones hearing it.

Fields.MenuText: Great. So much for a unified front.
Still doesn't bother me as much as surviving the next hour.
If it's true, we'll deal with it.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Mr. Cassel. Back to your station.
Right. Yes, sir.
@BATTLE
We'll defeat whatever enemy we face. Human and otherwise.
Imagine what it would take to create one.
You heard the Germans bombed the Firth of Forth?
Yeah.
Seems like this is getting away from us, huh?
I'm not giving up on a unified fleet yet, Lieutenant.
The Brits and the Germans are both understandably concerned with access to Scandinavia. I think it's time we aim for big wins. The Skagerrak blockade. The Oslo blockade. The North Sea.
You think they'll be more likely to listen to us if we earn a bigger spotlight?

Fields.MenuText: That's the hope.
No. I think if we poke the Morganas hard enough, they'll start attacking everyone in the region, and that'll be a healthy reminder.
Even if it doesn't work out that way, it needs doing for other reasons.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm.
... Damn, Captain. Respectfully.
Fair enough.
So. Any insights from the late Mughal Empire you can share?
I don't know. Don't let your bankers think they'd be better off backing a different horse.
Sorry?
Seems to me your reputation for pulling off miracles is your biggest asset, Captain. If you call attention to it and don't deliver... I don't know. Things get a lot harder.

Fields.MenuText: Noted.
My crew and the lady of the ship are my biggest assets, Lieutenant. That's where the reputation comes from.
Hey, now. Remember who you're talking to.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
All right, then. Pull off a miracle. Shouldn't be hard.
@BATTLE
Now that's a house I don't mind building.
That right there is why I'll never forget.
Matter of fact. That ought to get us pretty far.
So, this is where we stand. There are known to be dozens - maybe scores - of Morganas prowling in the Skagerrak Strait. German U-boats are getting by them, but not much else.
Oslo is totally blockaded. Not under sustained bombardment, but suffering from what's being called Type 1 mist - not extremely lethal, but dangerous to people with breathing difficulties.
Best estimate is about thirty avoidable civilian deaths a day. And, of course, they can't fish, they can't move cargo - it's going to get worse.
The Soviet Baltic Fleet has been deployed to protect Leningrad, and German forces are trying to patrol from Kiel to Danzig Bay.
As far as the British and French are concerned, the Germans and the Morganas have been de facto allies in British waters.
And, for the record, the U.S. and most of Latin America are in favor of a neutrality fleet on paper. How much they're willing to risk to make it happen I don't know.
As far as the Japanese Navy is concerned, it seems they think they're on their own, but they're looking for... better.
Now, we have friends. Individual ships from different nations, often with their own mixed crews, have been willing to follow our lead.
But it's not enough.
We are currently approaching the Skagerrak Strait, and I intend to pry it open and free Oslo, as long as we can. Morganas from Kristiansand to Hirtshals have been reported heading to intercept.
Through the League of Nations, I've proposed that combined German and Soviet forces - as well as anyone else in the Baltic still in a position to help - move in from the east.
At the same time, with luck, British forces from the North Sea and the Channel, combined with French Atlantic resources, will assist from the north and west.
If we can box the Morganas in here - if we can prove to the world that they have no allies - then I think we'll have won the biggest victory against them since the start of September.
... A month ago, I would've asked Commander Granville what I was missing. And he would have told me, at length, what he'd learned from watching the negotiations at Brest-Litovsk in 1917 or something.
Now I'm asking all of you. I think Lieutenant McPhee believes that racking up a series of relatively small wins is better strategy than risking a big loss. Is that fair?
I'm just saying it's worth thinking about what the odds of that big loss are, Captain.

I have a question - are we sure the Nazi leadership isn't working with the Morganas? Because the British are right: what we've been seeing in these waters is U-boats and Morganas targeting the Allies.
Why are you presuming that this is even your problem?
Stop. You're embarrassing the medical department.
No, it's a serious question. You're the captain of a single ship, and from what I hear that's almost by accident.
And you're trying to organize a multinational crusade.
That's a loaded-
Let me finish.
That's a loaded word.
Let me finish! People in Holland might listen to you because of what you've done, but if you think you have the authority to lead the entire world because some fairy woman told you it's your job....
I don't think that's going to take you as far as you think it will.
You weren't here in September, though. You didn't see what we've seen.
I was here, and I think the angry woman is making an interesting point. I'm not sure the Kapitan's own country would love all these ideas.
They will when they see they work. Right, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: Let's keep things focused, people.
That's certainly the hope.
Let's be clear - I never thought this was going to be easy.

Fields.DialogueText: We're not here for an argument. We're here to identify weaknesses and opportunities.
Doctor van Geffen, you asked from where I derive my authority, and that's fair.

Fields.MenuText: The honest answer is that I'm just grabbing every chance I can steal and trying to earn trust as I go.
And, basically, I don't have authority. At best, I have influence.
Awkward as it is to say, yes, a lot of it comes from the Belles.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm unaware of any precedent for what we're fighting. The military structures we have in place, everywhere, weren't designed for a crisis on this scale.
I'm building the best response I can without breaking orders, and I'm hoping that other people will learn from what works.
I can't command other nations, or even my own, to act in the ways that strike me as most effective. All I can do is state my case, and try to test my arguments with the resources I've been given.
This obviously isn't a normal war against a normal enemy. I'm not saying I have any special qualities that give me unique insights - as far as I know, I don't.
But the Belles are the best weapons we've got. In a foundational sense they're our entire defense right now. And if they're listening to me, I'm obligated to use them as best I can.
I didn't ask you all here because I'm offering you a veto over my decisions. I believe it's time to move on the Skagerrak. I believe it's our duty, and my superior officers chose not to override me.
Mr. Cassel, it's my understanding that Rostock has been badly hit, and that the Morganas have made it very complicated for the German Army to secure the Hel Peninsula.
Hitler's even suggested in public speeches that the Morganas are the result of a Jewish conspiracy-
Of course he has.
And I think he even believes it. I think we are, in fact, all in this together.
Do you think the Brits and the French will agree? I can see the Germans and the Soviets wanting to help us bust them out of their cage at the Strait, but if you're in London or Paris....
*ALARM*
Lieutenant - I hope our efforts in the Channel have earned us a respectful hearing, at least. If anyone has any better ideas, I'm open to them.
Regardless, for now, we seem to be needed elsewhere.
Oh, good grief.
@BATTLE
And what about the people who want to see you fail? Be embarrassed?
It's a fair point, Captain. Maybe you're being given just enough rope to hang yourself.
But I don't take your concerns lightly. I can tell you that right now.
But if it's going to be hard, I'd rather have a say in how.
Seaman Kirishima? What're you doing out in the rain?
Hassle-free shower, Kanchou. It's all the rage.
Um. Yesterday didn't seem like a great time to bring it up, but - I've been wondering what you've heard about the Admiral Scheer.
If it's not presumptuous to ask.
It's not presumptuous, but I don't have any news. She ran into Morganas that seemed to be trying to blow up the Sloedam and she got in over her head.
Lost in action, no known survivors.
Okay. But some of the new Dutch guys in engineering say that just as she was about to be destroyed, witnesses say she vanished in a flash of blue light.
What witnesses? Real people, or just something somebody overheard at port?
I don't know. But supposedly it was visible from shore.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't make too much of "supposedly."
It's possible, I suppose. I've seen severely damaged Belles make some impressive escapes.
Another Morgana super-weapon?

Fields.DialogueText: Probably not. But I don't know how much scuttlebutt you hear, so... it just seemed worth mentioning. I'm sorry if it wasn't.
I know! And I'll tell you, I'm well on my way to seeing every inch of this ship, and it's not like we've gotten extra engines or anything.
You think? Oh, I've got to get onto one of those things someday. I mean, I was on the Hope, but I don't think she really counted as a proper Morgana.
Anyway. How are you?

Fields.MenuText: Increasingly wet.
Fine. Thank you.
Just waiting for the next attack.

Fields.DialogueText: We're getting close, then?
We should be.
Your problem is that you're stuck on the bridge all day. If you'd spent three hours down with the boilers, trust me, the rain would feel magical.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not on the bridge all day.
Granted.

Fields.DialogueText: So... any progress on yesterday's big plans?
No, wait! First, thank you for inviting me to be a part of that! I don't know why you did, but it... well, it was flattering.
You shouldn't complicate my argument with facts, Kanchou. It's not polite.
Heh.

Fields.MenuText: It was our Belle's idea, actually.
I wanted a range of viewpoints from people I know are smart. You qualify.
You didn't say much.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh. Wow. That's also flattering.
That's really kind.
Well... yes. I'm a terrible public speaker. And I wanted to think about things, too.
So... because this is stupid, I don't suppose anyone's said anything like it to you yet.
But my outlook about bargaining was really, really shaped by my mother, who couldn't abide conflict in any way, shape or form. She'd smile serenely through an argument and go throw up in the kitchen.
And the rules she taught me basically boiled down to: never say no to anybody if you can help it. Just find the smartest possible way to say yes.
Which got me into all sorts of trouble with boys, by the way.
But I guess if it were me, I would try to frame things so that the British, or whoever, feel like you're going out on a limb and doing exactly what they want you to do.
Then you just do something else, and then show them why it's a win anyway. So, like, "I need a British fleet to keep Skagerrak Morganas from raiding London!"
Then, a week later, "We just saved Oslo! Your navy's getting amazing press! And London's safer than it ever was! And, yeah, I guess the Germans helped too, but so what?"

Fields.MenuText: That does sound like you.
I don't hate the approach, but I think our situation's a little more complicated than your example.
... I'll be watching you, Kirishima.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. Hehhhh.
I know. But-
Um. Is that good or bad?
*ALARM*
So much for my shower.
@BATTLE
Mr. Cassel, I don't suppose we've had any word of British reinforcements?
Not so far. But the interference is pretty bad.
Frankly, it might actually be best if they don't show up. If we can't coordinate with them, there's a lot that could go wrong.
Belle-to-Belle communications in battle seem reliable enough.
Captain?
It's going to be a hard fight, August. The Germans and the Soviets are somewhere on the other side of Denmark.

Fields.MenuText: And realistically, while we're attracting Morganas here, the British Army has its best chance in weeks for passage across the Channel.
And I guess we just have to make do.
I'd be lying if I said I was totally unhappy about that.
But, then, nobody ever said it was going to be easy.
What do you think? Turn around and cut for Bora Bora?

Fields.DialogueText: No, they did not.
If they don't have Morganas in Bora Bora yet, it's just a matter of time.

Fields.MenuText: Right.
Way to kill a daydream, Mr. Cassel.
That actually sounds like an argument for going.

Fields.DialogueText: Phew. All right.
Brace yourself, Mr. Cassel. It's time to go knock on Oslo's door.
@BATTLE
For the duration of the peace and quiet. Or the rum ration, whichever runs out first.
You're in good company.
We've had plenty of practice.
I've trained my whole life for it, sir.
Captain!
I'm here.
So are they.
@BATTLE
I see you got knocked around this time. Hold still.
Not the first time I've banged my head against something, Doctor. The blood in my eyes isn't any fun, but I'm fine.
Shut up and let me shine a light into your eyes.
Doctor van G. says I don't have to do this after every battle.
That's because she doesn't care if you die. Horrible woman. How many fingers am I holding up?
Three.
Right. You're either fine or a good guesser.
So. Is it just me, or are those things getting meaner?
They've been harvesting raw materials from Norway, Sweden, and Denmark for weeks. They're just in better shape than what we were seeing a month ago.
As opposed to us.
It's what it is. We're getting a sense of how these infestations work - the more noise we make, the more Morganas come out of the fjords to snipe at us and salvage the remains of their colleagues.
I'd say it's going well, except for the fact that our reinforcements from the west don't seem to be coming and the combined German-Soviet assault to the east isn't breaking through.
So... it's going well except for the fact that we're losing?

Fields.MenuText: No. This isn't totally unexpected.
Remind me not to make you morale officer.
Wish you'd deserted after all?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm too tired to wish for anything anymore. I'm just going to shamble along doing my job until somebody gives me a medal and tells me to take a nap.
Your loss. I'm told my bedside manner is impeccable.
... Maybe you do have a concussion.
Gentlemen. Seaman Kirishima. Taking in the Oslo air?
Kanchou! Orest is taking bets on how many supplies we can get loaded before Morganas reappear. Do you want in?
Nyet! The Captain has access to privileged information.
Says the man who's been grifting around the dock since the moment we arrived.
Da. Exactly. I'm an expert in managing risk.
By the way, Captain - if you have any use for French depth charges, I think something can be arranged.
... What?
I've been asking around.
That's not the sort of thing you just find lying in a crate by the side of the road.
Maybe you don't go down the right roads?
Mm. It's a great mystery.

Fields.MenuText: Fine. Yes. I'll take whatever you're offering. Do what you need to do.
Let's not worry about depth charges right now. We've got enough on our plate.

Fields.DialogueText: No "Thank you?"
Less work for Lugin, then!

Fields.MenuText: Thank you.
Maybe when it arrives.
Maybe once I'm sure you're not profiting from this behind my back.

Fields.DialogueText: Pozhaluysta.
You're a hard audience.
Ahem. Is that the time?
Right. Finish your business here as quickly as you can. We should all be making our way back onboard.
So there are more Morganas incoming?
Of course there are. Don't tell me you bet that we were done, Cassel-kun!
Please don't call me that.
There are more Morganas - but more than that, we need to push east. I want to break that bottleneck on the Baltic before any more Morganas can come in from the North Sea.
You think we'll get more support from the Brits now that they've finished ferrying their troops?
You think they're in a hurry to see more U-boats?
I think we've had this conversation too many times and it's not getting us anywhere. Let's just do our jobs and-
*ALARM*
Ha! We'll discuss payment later, Cassel!
@BATTLE
First you complain about "Grumpy-kun," now this. You're a hard man to please.
Well. Those are some nasty-looking Morganas.
Great way to start a Sunday.
Don't take this the wrong way, but - did you get any sleep last night?
No. You?
I think I was asleep on my feet for a few minutes around 02:00. Good thing we had the klaxon going every five minutes or I might've sleepwalked into the drink.
You think they might actually be willing to engage us this time?
Maybe. Dropping badly-aimed bombs and lobbing shells from a ridiculous distance and daring us to chase after them hasn't done them a lot of good over the last... what, fifteen hours?
Assuming they're as tired as we are. Have any of the scientists weighed in on whether these things need sleep?
False Hope did.
Hope was already half-sunk. And more like a Belle than a Morgana, far as I can tell.
Hmm.
Any other news?
Two things. Most urgent is that our friends in the Baltic are on the verge of falling apart.
The Soviets are threatening to fall back to protecting Leningrad again, and the Germans are seeing Morgana building projects - if that's what you call them - along the Hel Peninsula.
You're saying after all this they're losing their Polish ports? Augie must be... I don't know. Impressed by the poetic justice?
I doubt the Poles are impressed.
True. What's the second thing?
League sources are reporting that the Admiral Scheer just reappeared in the north Atlantic.
You're kidding.
Apparently not. The Belle was on the verge of sinking, she decided to get away, and - bang. Dead on her feet but thousands of nautical miles west.
And... you don't sound happy about that.
The thing is, apparently Captain Ferneck and company came upon an American freighter carrying "contraband" somewhere off the Canadian coast and seized it.
They're on their way back east - with the captured ship in tow - using what they've grabbed to make themselves as close to combat-ready as they can.
The Americans are not pleased. The British are not pleased. The Germans are pointedly not apologizing.
I think the sea is near a tipping point, and here we are just hoping that Oslo stays liberated long enough to matter...
...and that the fleets we're actually trying to rescue have the stamina to wait for us to show up.
And we haven't slept in a day and a half.

Fields.MenuText: That about covers it.
Yeah, but who's counting?
Plus, we're about to be in a hell of a fight.

Fields.DialogueText: You heard the Doctor came back from his little vacation with crates of German amphetamines for the bridge crew? For situations just such as this?
... No. He never got around to mentioning it.
That may be because Doc van G. had it all tossed overboard. So I guess then the Doctor threw out all her Beethoven records and put jazz albums in the sleeves.
Then she told the cooks that he needs to be on a vegetable-only diet for his blood pressure. Sorry, boiled vegetables only. I figure they'll be throwing rotten eggs at each other inside of a week.

Fields.MenuText: Heh.
Y'know, this is just not the command I was expecting.
I guess we can have them do their doctoring from the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: I mean, at least they're relieving some tension. It's something we all-
*ALARM*
Huh. I think they mean it this time.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
So this has all been practice. Great.
I'm sure I'll think of something else if I give it enough time.
I think our daily flirtation with death makes their flirting more of a relief than an annoyance.
Fit a cot in there and the sky's the limit.
Any luck getting a signal out, Mr. Cassel?
No luck getting a response, anyway.
Captain?
Keep trying. If I can't get the Germans and the Soviets to work together long enough to break out of the Baltic, the Neutrality Fleet's months away at best.
We're maybe a day away from the big fight for Copenhagen, and I need to be shouting at people. We can't win the war here, but we can lose it.
... Captain, I should say, it's not just interference. One of the Morganas is broadcasting a message of her own, and she's putting a lot of power into it.
Disinformation?
I... don't know what it is. The Morganas are saying that the British sent HMS Emerald to North America loaded with gold to buy war materiel.
And that the Morganas took out her engines, but don't care about the gold. And then some coordinates.

Fields.MenuText: I don't suppose it's anywhere we can easily reach.

Fields.DialogueText: No.

Fields.MenuText: And they're sending this message out in German, I assume?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja.
What are you thinking, Captain?
Right. Well, I can make one educated guess - the Morgana blocking our radio transmissions is Mischief.
Oh. Oh... that's good.
If we hit her hard enough, we can get our own message out. And hopefully the Kriegsmarine won't get a chance to infuriate London before we can do anything about it.
@BATTLE
Okay, Captain. I don't know if anyone's listening, but the microphone is yours.
... Hello.
To any human being who can hear this, I am... what matters is that I'm the captain of a warship. And every day since the first of September I and my crew have fought the enemy that threatens you now.
Every day we've won. And then the next day there are more.
I know you've seen the same things we have. I know it's exhausting, and I know it can seem like the only smart thing to do is to protect what's yours and just say a prayer for the rest.
But I will say this. I - my crew and I - fly under the flag of one nation and of the League of Nations, and against this foe there is no conflict between those mandates.
I don't care who you are. Danish, Swedish, Polish, German, Finnish, Latvian, Lithuanian, Soviet - I don't care. You are my allies against the Morganas, and I will not let you down.
Tomorrow, we're moving to break the Skagerrak blockade, once and for all. If you have guns, if you have a warship, above all if you have a Belle, join us.
I know what I'm asking you to risk, and I don't ask lightly - but together we can win. It's the only way we can.
I promise you. I promise, if you fight tomorrow, it will be remembered. I will keep the faith until the day I die.
The League of Nations will keep that faith.
And, Morganas, if you're listening, you come out too. Saves us having to hunt you down later.
... Thank you. I'll see you all tomorrow.
Done?
Done.
You forgot the Estonians. I didn't want to knock you off your stride, but....
Next time. I'll do one of these broadcasts every hour until the fight. So people know we're out here. And next time I'll make it up to the Estonians.
But... I mean, you really ought to sleep. Shouldn't you?

Fields.MenuText: I'll take naps.
I don't think I could if I tried.
What's that got to do with anything?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Understood.
Awful lot of Morganas out there this morning, Captain.
Awful lot of *cough* Germans and Soviets on the other side of those Morganas, Lieutenant.
Huh. Don't you sound ragged. Your career as a radio star off to a rough start?

Fields.MenuText: If we win, I'd say I did okay.
You know, you've never really felt like an idiot until you've delivered a speech about hope to an empty room at three in the morning.
Let's save the chatter until my voice comes back.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah. Yeah, if we win, I'd say so too.
I'll take your word on that, Captain.
Yes, sir.
They held on. They all held on. I honestly wasn't sure they *cough*-
Excuse me.
Okay, Lieutenant. Ready to let some sunlight into the Baltic Sea?
I mean, since you went and promised we would, I don't see we've got a lot of choice.
@BATTLE
We're out here fighting for our future. It's worth being dragged kicking and screaming into.
All right, people. This shouldn't be as hard as yesterday - but let's not get careless.
As soon as they're in range....
@BATTLE
So after all that we're not going into the Baltic? You look like hell, by the way.
Yeah? Well, you're not wearing any trousers.
I am! They're just... lightly shredded above the knee. I'm told it's all the rage in Paris this year.
Uh-huh. You need to make peace with Dr. van G., Doctor - a few practical jokes are all well and good in peacetime, but we don't need the distraction now.
Noted. I also note that you changed the subject.
Your knobby knees changed the subject.
Look. Investigating the Morganas' Baltic activities wasn't the goal. Opening the Baltic was.
And now that that's done - for however long it lasts - our priority has to be keeping the Morganas from escalating the sea war between Germany and Britain.
And neither side really trusts us, by the way. As far as the Brits are concerned, we just spent weeks fighting to give the U-boats easy access to British ports...
... and as far as the Germans are concerned, we kept the Morganas from blocking a British invasion of the Continent. More or less.
I know - it's terrible. And on top of all that, our captain's on the verge of collapse!

Fields.MenuText: Not true.
I don't have time to collapse.
I know, I know. I'm going to get some sleep right after I check in with the engineers.

Fields.DialogueText: You know you're talking to the man who's feeling what's passing for your pulse right now, right?
Tell it to your body.
I seem to recall you telling me something like that about seven hours ago. How did that turn out?
Look, you don't have to tell me I'm tired.
And dehydrated.
It's not that-
When was the last time you had to go to the head?

Fields.MenuText: ... Point taken.
I don't know. Before the battle.
I'm not comfortable having this conversation with a man with no pants.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen, there's a fine line between pushing your limits and outright recklessness, and I think you jumped over it about two days ago and just kept running.
You need to-
Captain? Doctor. Sorry to interrupt - but we've just had word that the British sank a U-boat in the Dover Strait. We've got somebody from the League on the radio who-
I'm on it. Thanks for the check-up, Doctor.
Mm.
... Something's different about you, Doctor. New haircut?
Shut up.
Fanny's conference in Zurich is in less than a week. If it fails, I don't know what comes next.
So if I don't do everything in my power to make it work, then our Belle chose me for nothing. I might as well have been dead on the deck on the first of September.
... That may be the single dumbest thing I've heard in my entire career as-
Remarkable where people will draw their lines.
I swear I could throw you off a cliff and you wouldn't fall until you looked down.
Another rainy day, another hassle-free shower?
Hai! I should've brought soap.
What about you, Kanchou?
Oh, you know. The Doctor's been hassling me about being dehydrated. I thought I might just stand here with my mouth open.
Wow. You're so clever, Kanchou!
... I can never tell if you're sincerely enthusiastic or just have a weird sense of humor.
Orest might be willing to take bets if you're interested.
Heh.
Augie says you've been on the radio all morning?
Arguing for an Anglo-German naval cease-fire to anyone who would listen. They're not actually shooting at each other on land yet, as far as I can tell - it's just out here.
Where we have other things to worry about.
Can't you just bypass them? I mean, what you were doing in the run on Copenhagen seemed to work - get on the radio and appeal to the people directly.
You're probably more popular than any politician in the world after the last two months. People would listen.

Fields.MenuText: We're in our own little bubble out here. We don't really know how anybody else sees us.
I'm good-looking, too.
I'll talk to anybody who'll listen. But right now we need governments on our side.

Fields.DialogueText: Mm-hm. And I'm sure that would come across on the air!
You really think so? I mean, we win a lot of battles. Winning has to matter.
Hey. You know what Bertie would do right now? If he had your job?
Tell me.
He'd take a nap.

Fields.MenuText: No, he wouldn't.
The Doctor got to you too, huh?
You know the alarm's going to go off instantly if I agree with you, right?

Fields.DialogueText: He would, because Fanny would make him.
No!
I mean, yes, but everybody can see how hard you've been working. It's not just him saying it.
Shoot. Okay, I grant your point.
Anyway, I actually did get a couple of hours of sleep last night.  Right now I've got bigger problems.
As far as I can tell, Mischief has resurfaced - telling the Germans where to look for the British treasure ship, and telling the Brits where to look for the Admiral Scheer and her captured freighter.
So all we need to do is set up a Neutrality Fleet and get everyone to agree to get along while they're distracted by their various prizes.
Again, I can't tell if you're joking.
I dunno. Ask me when the war's over.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mōichido ihan ni....
Don't let up on the speed - and somebody sound the klaxon! We need to get these things' attention before they get firing range of Hartlepool!
@BATTLE
I need damage reports, ASAP. As long as we're near the British coastline, we have opportunities - but at the same time, we can't afford-
Roll up your sleeve.
Don't have the time. I'm sure Dr. van Geffen could use another pair of hands in sick bay. Or in the corridor outside sick bay. I'll find you there in a bit.
If you don't want me to declare you unfit for duty and have you lashed to a bed for twenty-four hours, I suggest you-

Fields.MenuText: You're out of line.
You do not want to escalate things with me right now, Doctor.
Doctor, please. Give me ten minutes and then I will jump through every hoop you've got.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I don't. I just want to make sure your ticker's keeping time.
Then chew me out as I take your pulse.
Captain, your bridge crew has fought this kind of fight every day for two months. They can do their jobs over the next ten minutes without you reminding them how to do it.

Fields.MenuText: I've been extremely tolerant of your little visits to the bridge so far, Doctor, but you're abusing my patience.
No.
Fine. Make it fast. And Lieutenant, get me those-

Fields.DialogueText: I understand you think your well-being doesn't matter, but-
Sleeve. Up. Now.
Will you just-
Captain? I'm sorry to interrupt, but we just had word from the League, and... and I thought you'd want to hear it.

Fields.MenuText: How bad is it?
What now?
Are you crying, Mr. Cassel?

Fields.DialogueText: No. I just....
The League just thought you should know... um... on Wednesday, there were no mist-related fatalities in Copenhagen. And Rotterdam. And Oslo.
For the first time since the war started, in those three cities, there weren't any... the Morganas didn't kill anybody.
One peek, Doctor. Make it count.
Get back to work, people. And good job. All of you.
... Not.
Listen, man, I get it. I do. And if you want to burn a badge, I'll help you light the fire. I just don't think getting caught up on the symbolism is going to get you anything.
Tell that to the damn Nazis.
Gentlemen. What's going on?
Nothing. I'm just trying to find a way to- nothing.
It's not nothing. The Germans are cracking down on Polish Jews, and-
I mean, you're absolutely right, Lieutenant. What would really make me feel better is watching  the Brits sink U-boats. I know that's against the party line, but-

Fields.MenuText: So let's change the subject.
Me, too.
I'll try not to take it personally.

Fields.DialogueText: But if we're going to have any chance against the Morganas, at least the navies have to work together. You know the argument by now.
Ja. We have to be nice to all the world's worst people in the hopes that they'll agree to let us save them from an alien nightmare so they can keep on being their own kind of monster.
So how's it going, Captain? Anybody bomb the Firth of Forth today?

Fields.MenuText: If you have a better idea, I'm open to suggestions.
Yeah.
The more successful we are, the more influence we have. These are the first steps in more than one campaign.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad at least one of us is an optimist.
You know I don't. It's just so....
Yeah.
No. As far as I know, the British and the Germans have been avoiding each other since the sinking of U-16 the other day. I hear the Germans are keeping out of the Dover Strait, which helps.
But the thinking is that the Admiral Scheer is heading for Norway, assuming her engines haven't given out, and I think that's the obvious flashpoint.
The British want to take her, the Germans see her as a heroic example, and the Morganas... who knows? Mischief's just poking bears with a stick.
So we're heading for the North Sea, so we can be in the running to find her too. And to win some British hearts and minds by keeping Morganas away from Scapa Flow.
"Cracking down?"
I'm not naive - but the League representatives I've talked to say that the Council of the League is open to giving the Minorities Section new powers if the talks in Zurich go well.
I promise you, I'm pushing that angle hard, and I'm going to keep pushing. I don't mean to let the Jewish people be friendless.
I don't think naive people necessarily know they're naive, Captain. No offense.

Fields.MenuText: A little bit of offense taken. I guess I'll have to prove you wrong.
Hey. If nothing else, you should know I'm not afraid of a hard fight.
I hope you're underestimating me. And the League.

Fields.DialogueText: And if we find U-boats active in British waters?

Fields.MenuText: We notify the League.
We shout at the top of our lungs.
We hope they're there to help us fight Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Is there a problem, Mr. Cassel?
You might as well say. If the Captain were going to throw you in the brig for speaking your mind, you'd probably be there already.
No, I don't... it's just, there's only so much we can do on our own, you know?
Captain, you're working yourself to the bone, the Germans are getting away with murder, the Morganas are hitting us every single day...
Does it feel to anybody else like we're winning the battles and losing the war? Does anybody think the Zurich Conference is actually going to make any difference?

Fields.MenuText: Yes.
I don't know. But I plan to keep winning the battles.

Fields.DialogueText: And, Mr. Cassel...

Fields.MenuText: We're not losing this. You hear me?
The Lieutenant's right. I'm not ever going to punish you for telling me what's on your mind.
There are a lot of Polish expatriates in the UK, and I imagine some are Jewish. I mean to get the word out we're asking for volunteers.

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes a little symbolism does matter.
I... yes, sir. Thank you.
*ALARM*
Well. I guess we're done here.
@BATTLE
Such a comfort.
Proper channels. Of course. We're not savages here.
I hate to say it, but hope seems to work for us now and again.
*KNOCK*
Enter.
You're too kind.
I don't hear that very often.
Well, you don't often ask for a house call. It's a night for strange happenings, I guess.
So it seems.
... So, are you going to tell me what's going on?
You know, the other day I was this close to promising August we were going to make all Germany love the Jews.
So you're delirious.
Kind of feels like it.
Six weeks ago, my job was just: keep everybody alive, learn what we can about the Hope, find our way home.
And then Bertie died, and for some reason I started promising everyone we would save the world. I think it's literally becoming a habit.
Keep talking, but let me check your pulse.
I think it's going to be a mess.
I'm not missing sleep because I'm being defiant. I just can't do it. It's not coming. I lie in that bunk and I try to imagine how I can get from where we are now to where we need to be.
I can hardly hold my food down. I mean, I don't feel nauseated all day or anything, but my appetite is just... I would say it's not a factor. But it should be. I have dizzy spells sometimes.
Yeah, you should probably force yourself to eat more than once a day.
Are you beating yourself up any other ways I should know about?
I don't think so. It's probably just as well that Dr. van G. tossed out your German favors, though. I might've picked up all sorts of bad habits.
You think?
I don't know. Listen, I probably shouldn't ask, but... you're about the only person I talk to anymore who knew me before I was "the Captain."

Fields.MenuText: Am I screwing this up?
Ever wish our Belle had picked somebody else?
Is it just me, or have I gotten better looking?

Fields.DialogueText: Hell. Probably. Who wouldn't?
If you're asking if I want the job, hell no.
Delirium. Check.
Listen, I knew the whole crew before you became "the Captain." I don't know that you would've been first choice even then, but you would've been in the top twenty.
And I would've been underestimating you.
Don't get me wrong. I don't think you're a messiah. You absolutely have set yourself up to fail with this whole Neutrality Fleet idea.
But if those kids in your crew serve another fifty years in the Navy - whatever navy - I think I can already guarantee that when they talk about "the Captain," they're only going to mean one person.
You're doing an impossible job, and you're doing it well. But I'm gonna have to find something to help you sleep.
Good. In a couple of days.
... Are you just screwing with me now?
Did you know that Belles gossip? I mean, from ship to ship? I don't know how, but they do.
And?
Tomorrow, the odds are pretty good that HMS Rodney - carrying the First Lord of the Admiralty, through sheer dumb luck - will intercept the German heavy cruiser Admiral Scheer.
The Scheer is captained by one of Germany's greatest heroes in the battle against the Morganas. It has also intercepted, and possibly sunk, an American cargo ship.
The Brits want to take prisoners, or make an example, both for themselves and as a statement to the United States.
There are a bunch of German U-boats determined to make sure that doesn't happen.
Tomorrow may be the day everything goes off the rails. I probably shouldn't be in a chemical haze.
You probably shouldn't have been awake for thirty-plus hours when it happens, either.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, I know. It's a kicker, isn't it?
Okay. Agreed.
I should be able to get at least an hour or two out cold tonight.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen, I'll just-
*ALARM*
You've got to be kidding me!
*sigh*
It's okay, Doctor. We'll make it through.
@BATTLE
An eight-legged mule.
I suppose ninety-nine percent insane is a step in the right direction.
What's going on?
You shouldn't be here, is what's going on.
Listen, let's just say something in the radio room needs to be oiled, all right? Probably you.
Now what's going on?
Right. We're currently trying to stay close enough to a U-boat for our Belle to manifest inside their hull and beg their captain not to shoot any more torpedoes at HMS Rodney.
"Any more?"
They've already hit Rodney with a dud.
So now Rodney's bearing down on the Admiral Scheer, we're babysitting U-56, and there are Morganas somewhere around in the mist waiting to make things worse.
That was enough to make the Lord Admiral cut off radio contact with us - after chewing the Captain out for "pretending being at war means something other than being at war."
We're not at battle stations because the Captain doesn't want to signal that we're prepared to fire on human ships, but....
Well.
So... it's time for an awesome, inspiring Captain speech?
There's only so inspirational I can be, Seaman.

Fields.MenuText: I can't convince the Germans to forget about Versailles.
I can't convince Churchill that Germany's going to stay in her own borders.
I can't pretend the war isn't happening.

Fields.DialogueText: So... what are you going to do?

Fields.MenuText: Kick you out of the radio room.
Hopefully, get the Morganas to attack and remind everyone else we still have a common enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Haaaiiiiii.
Attention, all human vessels in listening range.

Fields.MenuText: Some of you have made it very clear that you're sick of the sound of my voice.
You know who I am. You know what my crew and I have done.
I'm asking you to take your fingers off your triggers for ten minutes to hear me out.

Fields.DialogueText: You think I'm trying to wish away the war in Europe. I'm not.
You know what my crew and I have survived.
It's not just us out here. That's not the world we live in anymore.
I know none of you would be out here right now, breathing normally, if your ships didn't have active Belles.
They'll have told you that Morganas are close by. That the enemy is close by.
Some of you will have fought these things directly. Some of you will just have heard stories.

Fields.MenuText: But you know about the coastal death tolls. You know what they did to Rotterdam.
Either way, you know they're nobody's allies. You know they're not here because they wish us well.
It doesn't matter. You're going to learn all you need to know about them any minute now.

Fields.DialogueText: They're waiting for us to turn on each other. They're waiting for us to weaken ourselves. They're trying to poison the air we're breathing right now, though our Belles are stopping them.
Out here, on the water, there's only one enemy. And they're waiting for us to defeat ourselves.
Because they're weaker than they want us to think. Because they're cowardly. Because they're too broken to think of a better-
Hello? Can anybody hear me?
... Sorry. Who is this?
You can hear me? Crap! Herr Kap'tän! We're getting through!
Is she a Belle?
What? No. No, sorry, my name's Angie - Angela - Miller. I'm acting radiowoman for the Admiral Scheer. Just... three seconds, please.
Are you American?
No. Heck, no. Canadian! Just...
This is Kapitän zur See Erich Ferneck, commanding officer of the Admiral Scheer. Kapitän, it's an honor to make your acquaintance, even in circumstances such as these.
Attention, Admiral Scheer. This is HMS Rodney. Stand down and prepare to be boarded.
We will do no such thing.... But we will not be the first to fire.
Then that will make things a great deal easier for us.

Fields.MenuText: Let's all be polite, HMS Rodney.
That's a good start, Kapitän. Let's see if we can build on it.

Fields.DialogueText: We understood the Admiral Scheer to be traveling with an American cargo ship. The SS Pan Kraft.
Lost. We had to scuttle it to keep it from the enemy. As you say, our real enemy out here.
That would be more bloody convincing if you hadn't committed an act of piracy to secure it in the first place. We will be-
What happened to the crew of the Pan Kraft, Kapitän?
They're here. On board. Some have done me - done us - the great honor of taking temporary positions among our crew. Others are our guests. I consider none of them to be prisoners.
I can vouch for that! Most of the German crew have been really swell.
And we committed no piracy. The Pan Kraft was carrying contraband that-
You can explain after you've surrendered.
That will not happen.
Kapitän, would you be willing to surrender yourself and your ship to the League of Nations? The piracy charges could be independently adjudicated, and the status of your crew-
That's not on bloody offer!
Britain's a League signatory! You think you're not going to have a chance to have a say?
This is it! Out here, like it or damn not, this is our choice!
We work with the League - the best single tool humanity has ever built to fix big problems - or we shoot each other and let the Morganas eat the pieces!
Kapitän... what you're asking....
I know.
... We will surrender to the League.
Rodney? Come on!
... We will need to talk about where the Scheer will be taken.
Fine. Yes. By all means, let's-
*BOOM*
Damn pieces of-
Rodney, Scheer - I don't think the Morganas like what they're hearing. Table the discussions until after they're dead?
That's pretty much the whole story of our last couple of weeks.
Angela....
Sorry!
@BATTLE
Wait.
Then you-
Wait!
Captain! Good to see you!
Well, well. The hero of the hour.

Fields.MenuText: I'm here for food, not congratulations.
"Set myself up to fail with the Neutrality Fleet," my ass.
Too many heroes to count this time.

Fields.DialogueText: What, you think you've done it?
No. But I don't think we've failed. Thank you, Kapitän zur See Ferneck and thank you, Admiral Churchill. Even if they both hated every second of it.
Well, you're getting both!
If that includes me, I prefer my medals in gold.
I hope you've all learned to ignore him by now.
Yeah, pretty much.
I ignore all of you.
It's the only sensible approach.
You will find that the congratulations taste better than the food.
Hear, hear.
So, what now?
The Admiral Scheer goes briefly to Bergen with a British escort, then to Rotterdam. Hopefully the League then impresses the world with its wisdom and far-sightedness.
So we're all doomed.

Fields.MenuText: Yep. Ignoring you.
Lieutenant, do me a favor and slap Mr. Lugin on the side of the head.
Probably. Where's the salt?

Fields.DialogueText: Locked and loaded.
Mm. That's fair.
Oh. Sorry!
... Can I ask a stupid question?
Past experience would suggest you can.
How long did I just sleep?
It's Halloween. 1939.
So it's the first day of the Zurich Conference.
Yep.
Well. This should be fun.
Shut up, Lugin.
